PROFESSOR STRANG: So,
shall we start, as always, just open for questions. About any topic.

And I should have

certainly topics that are in this part of the course.

We didn't really get to

words about curl today. Anyway, questions.

PROFESSOR STRANG:
Ooh, let's see. So A^T A for a truss. That's a good question.

Trusses, A^T A. I guess I don't

so one way is to construct

So those are already in

They're little A element,

this isn't a great

Possibly by looking at the

Just, there's a

So I would expect Au=0

You don't know the exact

There could be more

this guy would-- this u

This wouldn't move. So I'm putting in the four

This one, what would be the

In a rotation? So my rotation is just swing

Zero? [0, -1], I think. Right. Because it's not

It's going to go

Times a positive slope. And I'm really only integrating

The two overlap only here,

Having used those words. Suppose I take that function.

With constant ratio z squared. If I multiply that

Is there any other place

When z is minus i we'll

So the physical

It's equal to second derivative

And the book, of

So I'll stop there with

tremendously important.

It measures vorticity and flow,

I'd say primary variables

But you could also use

in terms of other variables. Just rewrite the equation

Mentioning Navier-Stokes and

we keep using the example

a minute, get beyond that.

Right? So why are you always, when
you teach finite elements,

why do you always start
with Laplace's equation? OK, well the main reason
is it's the simplest one.

It's the one where you can
really see what's happening. More complicated
equations would be for,

like, elasticity, plane
elasticity, or 3-D elasticity or other boundary value
problems could be quite messy.

But Laplace's equation is
not totally a waste of time.

First, it comes up when you
have these scalar unknowns. And then it also comes
up in numerical methods

for Navier-Stokes. So the standard numerical
method for Navier-Stokes,

which would come
in 18.086, ends up

with Laplace's equation
for the pressure. So to have a fast Laplace
solver, as in today's lecture,

pays off. So I'm just saying
Laplace's equation is important in itself,
it has the great advantage

of being the simplest example
we could possibly think of. It's the example where
an x+iy trick works.

And it actually comes up in
serious big computations,

because the equation
for the pressure comes out to be a Laplace
or a Poisson equation.
